STRINGS: "Mr. Kanaya was horrible, too. He treated me whichever way he wanted.
So much, in fact, I thought at least Mr. Takenaka was still polite."
"Furthermore, he wasn't skilled at inter-personal communication
in the least, wouldn't you agree?"
Can't deny that.
"I believe human connections are formed when you
surmise another person's feelings and share them.
That concept also applies to care working."
"But he forced his feelings unto me."
"Can you believe it?
He would grind me down to enact his emotions,
all the while whispering in my ear-- 'Haruka, Haruka'."
"The animalistic desires he couldn't realize with Ms. Haruka Minase
were instead vented on me.
Honestly speaking, it was humiliating, you know?"
"Ms. Haruka Minase was his first choice, and me, the second fiddle.
He plainly announced me that. Over and over again."
"I couldn't endure those conditions for any longer.
My rage, anguish, and sorrow at denying myself reached its limits."
"So I decided to discipline Mr. Kanaya.
But I had no way to rival his authority,
he held photographic evidence that outweighted everything."
"Even if I killed him like Mr. Takenaka,
it would only be a matter of time until they traced it back to me.
Hence, after much thought, I lured him into ruining himself."
"...Ruining himself...?"
"I pushed the buttons of his complex.
I told him that if he tried his best to slim down,
Ms. Haruka Minase would surely turn his way."
"Of course, considering his personality, it was obvious
he would never follow harsh exercise and dietary routines.
But it wasn't like I wanted him to honestly slim down."
"--The Samadhi Medical Diet."
"Correct! You've identified so far as the name, I see.
It's truly surprising the things you're able to sell without issue
in Southeast Asia with its crude drug legislation, you know?"
"No need for exercising. Dietary restrictions, unnecessary.
The drug stimulates the satiety center, preventing overeating.
It was like it was made for Mr. Kanaya."
"After he began taking it,
I would inform him of Ms. Haruka Minase's reactions."
"I hadn't seen him for some time, but his impression changed
after slimming down a little, she said. She was surprised at how
sharp and masculine your cheek lines and face had become. Etcetera."
"Men really are idiots, aren't they?
He took the nonsense that spewed out of my mouth as fact."
"It was true that he had lost a tiny bit of weight.
But that drug... it seemingly had some slight side effects."
That's putting what happened to Hiromu Kanaya lightly.
I wanted to vent my frustration, but since she showed
no signs of stopping her story, I held myself back with some effort.
"It intensified his natural predisposition to
get lost in his fantasies.
He believed Ms. Haruka had been seduced by a bad guy or something."
"He would whisper that he had to change to combat this bad guy
while delightfully gulping down the medicine."
"When that delusion reached its zenith,
this time I was the one to whisper.
I taught him a killing method that would make
his target feel the greatest horror."
"You should take tight hold of some scissors,
and while taking in his screams, stab through both his eyes.
Your now blind victim will die cowering before your might, I said."
"Blindly trusting me,
Mr. Kanaya soon after murdered Ms. Haruka Minase's lover.
In accordance to Blindman's M.O., just as I told him."
"Perhaps one of his screws went loose then,
because his delusions took over, and he murdered his entire family...
You are well aware of what happened after, yes?"
"Yeah. Because of you, Mr. Kazamori left this world."
"Please don't misunderstand.
It wasn't me. The one who perpetrated that act was Mr. Kanaya."
"If you hadn't given him that drug, this could've been avoided."
"You can go on forever if you think like that, you know?
This could have been avoided if only you didn't go talk with him.
This could have been avoided if only he didn't meet with Ms. Haruka--"
"You can establish whatever you wish as the cause.
So please cease trying to pin the blame on me.
He became consumed by his delusions. That's all there is to it."
"Now, after he murdered Ms. Haruka's beloved,
his fantasies hauled him every which way.
Luckily, he didn't care about me anymore."
"It was quite refreshing.
I finally obtained the freedom I eagerly waited for.
However... that was also the beginning of my anxiety."
"Were you afraid the investigation might expose you?"
Ms. Sanae languidly shook her head.
"Mr. Kanaya had already become dependent on the drug.
Hence, even if he testified, his confession would have no credibility.
My anxiety had nothing to do with that."
"What worried me was that now I would live alone
in this depopulated town, unneeded by anyone.
When I thought about that, I couldn't sit still."
"I would soon become qualified as a caretaker.
But so what?
Nobody would congratulate me. I was alone."
"Who in this world would need me now?
That anxiety dwelled within me ever since
I was threatened by Mr. Kanaya."
"The person who would need me.
The person who needs me...
At that moment, I hit upon a realization."
"There is someone who genuinely needs me.
In fact, it's not just one person, but many."
"The people in the home you worked at... right?"
Even as I inquired, I was half in doubt.
Because it didn't seem like she came across anybody like that.
"Fufufu. It's written all over your face,
you don't expect that to be the right answer."
"Let me give you an example, this guy--"
Ms. Sanae stretched her arm to point to the bucket.
The bloodstained hand, in concert with her introduction,
almost seemed to greet me.
"People like him all became corpses for a single reason.
Because I did it.
Without me, they couldn't have died."
"And at the same time, if I hadn't acted,
Blindman couldn't have come into this world."
"...What are you talking about?"
"To the people who believe in Blindman,
my deeds are absolutely essential.
It is because I kill that Blindman exists."
"They need me.
That sense of fulfillment drives me to act.
Whenever I run across an outsider, I bring and deal with them here."
"Someone like you understands that feeling, don't you, Ms. Houjou?"
I don't understand, nor do I want to.
Victimizing others just to satisfy your vanity.
The mentality of a thrill killer isn't I wish to comprehend.
"Who are the others?
You said it wasn't just one person, right?"
"Yes. Among the others I spoke of
is someone you know very well--"
"--Professor Soujirou Sekimoto."
"Now that Mr. Takenaka is gone,
Professor Soujirou Sekimoto might hold interest in me.
He might even understand me."
"Since I'm the one who gave form to
the monster Professor Sekimoto created, Blindman!!"
"The days after I realized that were hectic.
Alongside my work at the welfare institution,
I took opportunities to keep dealing with out-of-towners here--"
"--The time I spent striving to become Blindman.
That alone might not be enough to get Professor Sekimoto to
notice me from the Tokyo Detention House."
"So I sent a number of letters.
Letters of affection to the father, Professor Sekimoto.
As the child, Blindman, otherwise known as me."
"Wait, what...!?
It was you who called Sekimoto here, then!?"
"It was an unexpectedly good piece of news for me.
I anticipated him to take some interest,
but never would I have imagined he would go so far...!"
"But his visit to C Town was supposed to be top secret...
Where did you find out about it?"
"Children can simply sense their parents' presence, you know."
...She's avoiding the question, I intuited.
Somebody leaked information to her.
"I wanted him to see how much I developed into 'his child'.
I wanted him to know I gave substance to Blindman's being."
"And above all, I wanted him to learn
how fast I developed."
"...Developed?"
'Dad, look! I can do it now!'
This was the very same mentality a child has
that wishes to show their growth to their parents.
"Ms. Wataru was easy.
She didn't struggle much."
"Even when I was taking care of her,
she wasn't the type to react to every little sensation."
"But it's right at times like those when she notices things.
I tricked her, saying we were going on a stroll,
at which point I brought her here, yet she was oddly scared
despite the fact I hadn't done anything yet."
"I thought it would go without issue since she had dementia,
but she was being quite astute, you see."
"Then she started running her mouth, muttering weird things,
so I stabbed out her eyes in a panic
and crammed a letter in her mouth."
"That's right, just as Professor Sekimoto established."
"...The way you appeared a few moments after
was very awe-inspiring, Ms. Houjou."
I wasn't overjoyed in the least at hearing such praise.
"But anyway, when I thought about how Professor Sekimoto
would discover this, I made my way back in high spirits."
"And what about Ms. Haruka Minase?"
"Oh. She gave me just a little trouble.
After all, she was young and energetic,
so even if we were in a deserted mountain road,
shouting at the top of her lungs wouls still be bad for me."
"So I had to hit her a few times to make her behave.
Just in case, I ripped out her underwear and jammed it
as deep in her throat as it could go, blergh--, she went."
"That kill gave me the greatest sense of accomplishment thus far.
You know why that is, don't you?
You do. You do, don't you!?"
"Because! I was able to directly show my work to Professor Sekimoto!
Never have I been so happy!"
"I was stealthily watching from amidst the trees
as you guys stopped the car as soon as you noticed her,
and the commotion that then ensued."
"Emotions were at such a high
I had to try my hardest to make sure I wouldn't let anything out."
"I had to place my hand on my chest to stabilize my feelings.
For I still had some things to do."
"Like killing the driver."
"You got it, yes, yes.
Compared to Ms. Haruka, it was disappointing.
I had no time to gouge out his eyes, you see."
"Although, the minivan falling down the cliff
was a happy accident."
"And that also killed Chief Kuroda-- my boss."
"Huh... Is that so?
But does that really matter?"
"After all, you'll shortly be able to be by their side once more.
You won't be lonely anymore."
"How did you know about our transport of Sekimoto?"
"It's quite simple. I merely watched you every day."
It's no use. She's completely mad.
Whatever pangs of consciousness she felt for committing murder
had completely faded by now.
"The end.
I have told you all the details you wanted to know."
"Now then!
It's your turn now."
The crude scheme I played on her to buy some time is over.
"Are you ready?"
"You aren't, are you?
Nobody wants to die, in the end."
"But I prefer it that way, it's more fun.
So, please, play along for the sake of
those who believe in Blindman's existence."
"Now, fearfully and painfully and irrationally
cry, wail, and beg for your life-- won't you?"
